text: O praise the LORD, all ye nations: praise him, all ye people.
text_kjv: O praise the LORD, all ye nations: praise him, all ye people.
text_niv: Psalm 117Praise the Lord, all you nations;extol him, all you peoples.
text_esv: Praise the LORD, all nations! Extol him, all peoples!
text_nlt: Praise the LORD, all you nations.Praise him, all you people of the earth.
text_msg: Praise God, everybody!Applaud God, all people!
text_nasb: Praise the LORD, all nations; Laud Him, all peoples!
context: Psalm 117 is the shortest psalm in the entire Psalter, comprised of only two verses. This brevity suggests it likely served a specific liturgical purpose, possibly as an introductory call to worship or a concluding doxology. The phrase 'praise the LORD' (Hebrew: *Hallelu Yah*) is a familiar refrain throughout the Psalms, emphasizing the importance of praising Yahweh, the covenant name of God. The call to 'all ye nations' and 'all ye people' is remarkable. In the historical context of ancient Israel, there was often a strong sense of national identity and separation from other nations. While Israel understood itself as God's chosen people, this psalm explicitly extends the invitation to praise God to all Gentiles. This inclusive call hints at the universal scope of God's grace and foreshadows the future expansion of God's kingdom to include all peoples, as prophesied by Isaiah and other prophets. The language used does not suggest forced conversion but rather an invitation to acknowledge and praise the God of Israel, recognizing His sovereignty and goodness. Understanding this universalistic element is key to grasping the radical nature of this short psalm within its historical setting. The psalm likely emerged during a time when Israel was experiencing either a renewed sense of God's favor or during a period when they were particularly aware of their relationship to surrounding nations. It might have been used in temple worship, festivals, or special occasions that highlighted God's blessings.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 117 is a powerful statement about the nature of God and His relationship with humanity. It affirms God's universal sovereignty, declaring that His worthiness of praise extends beyond the boundaries of Israel to encompass 'all nations' and 'all people.' This universality challenges any narrow or exclusive understanding of God's grace. The invitation to Gentiles to praise God underscores the idea that God's love and salvation are not limited to a particular ethnic group or geographical location. It anticipates the New Testament concept of the Church as a multi-ethnic, global community united in Christ. The brevity of the psalm focuses attention on the core message: God is worthy of universal praise. It implicitly acknowledges God's attributes, such as His power, goodness, and mercy, as the basis for this praise. Furthermore, the psalm highlights the importance of outward expression of faith. Praise is not merely an internal feeling but a vocal and communal act. The repetition of 'praise him' emphasizes the continuous and unwavering nature of this call to worship. This little psalm echoes the larger narrative of redemption found throughout Scripture. It points towards a future where all of creation will acknowledge and worship God, fulfilling His original intention for humanity. It serves as a reminder that the ultimate goal of God's plan is to reconcile all things to Himself, creating a unified community of worshippers from every nation, tribe, and tongue.
application: Psalm 117 challenges us to examine our own attitudes towards people from different backgrounds. Do we truly believe that God's love extends to all nations? Are we actively seeking ways to connect with and learn from people who are different from us? This psalm calls us to cultivate a more inclusive and welcoming spirit in our churches and communities. It reminds us that the Church is meant to be a reflection of God's universal kingdom, where people from all walks of life can come together to worship Him. Practically, we can apply this psalm by intentionally reaching out to people of different ethnicities, cultures, or social classes. This could involve volunteering in organizations that serve diverse communities, engaging in conversations with people who hold different perspectives, or simply making an effort to learn about different cultures. Furthermore, Psalm 117 encourages us to be vocal about our faith. We should not be afraid to share our experiences with God with others, even those who may not share our beliefs. Our praise can be a powerful witness to God's love and grace. It encourages us to find creative ways to express our faith, whether through music, art, writing, or simply acts of kindness and service. Consider what concrete actions you can take to embody the spirit of Psalm 117 in your daily life. How can you contribute to building a more inclusive and loving community? How can you use your voice and talents to praise God and share His message of hope with the world? The psalm also reminds us to remember the global church. We must remember to pray for Christians around the world, especially those facing persecution and hardship.
prayer: Lord, Your Word declares that all nations should praise You. Forgive me for the times I have limited my understanding of Your love to my own group or culture. Open my heart to embrace all people as Your children. Help me see the beauty in diversity and to celebrate the richness of Your creation. Empower me to reach out to those who are different from me with love and compassion. May my life be a testament to Your universal grace, and may my voice join the chorus of praise that rises from every corner of the earth. Help me to be more aware of the global Church. I pray for unity and understanding among all believers. Amen.

faqs.answer: The brevity likely indicates its specific liturgical function. It was probably used as a concise call to worship or as a doxology, focusing attention on the core message of universal praise.
faqs.question: Q1: Why is it significant that this Psalm is so short?

faqs.answer: It foreshadows the New Testament concept of the Church as a global community, comprised of people from every nation, tribe, and tongue, united in Christ.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this psalm relate to the New Testament?

faqs.answer: Praising the Lord involves acknowledging His attributes, such as His power, goodness, and mercy, and expressing our gratitude and adoration through vocal and communal acts of worship.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean to 'praise the LORD'?

faqs.answer: By intentionally reaching out to people from different backgrounds, being vocal about your faith, and finding creative ways to express your faith through service and kindness.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I apply this psalm in my daily life?

faqs.answer: It acknowledges Yahweh as the one true God, whose sovereignty extends over all creation and whose love and grace are available to all people, regardless of their origin.
faqs.question: Q5: Why does this psalm call all nations to praise Yahweh specifically?
